repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Water, Sanitation
            and Solid Waste Urgent Works Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is moderately satisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is unlikely, the institutional
            development impact is modest, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory overall. Two main lessons
            emerge from this project experience: 1) In an emergency
            reconstruction program, it is essential to have a workable
            coordination system in place to avoid duplication of effort
            and inconsistent applications of policy that lead to
            different treatment.  regimes. The objectives of this
            project were not attained at the planned level, as most
            funding aid-agencies opted to work on their own (instead of
            contributing to the agreed upon Sector Recovery Program
            (SRP)). The use of differing sets of policy and procedures
            caused confusion during project implementation, and
            unplanned overlaps in donor activities led to a reduction in
            the overall program scope. In the end, lack of coordination
            weakened sector reform activities, and prevented the phased
            implementation of the rest of the SRP operations within the
            anticipated timeframe. 2) The rapid post-emergency appraisal
            of operations sometimes requires flexibility, but it is
            still necessary that key components be fully defined within
            the project implementation period. In this case,
            institutional strengthening should have included
            well-specified and realistic activities that would have
            assisted sector agencies to improve operational efficiency
            in incremental steps. In the midst of hectic repair and
            rehabilitation efforts, institutional development measures
            such as reducing unaccounted water, improving efficiency and
            skills of staff and improving collection of bills, received
            lower priority. A stepwise package of the most urgent
            measures should have been defined in the project documents
            to ensure that the various entities could take needed first
            steps to return to normal operations after the crisis.

2851592.trustfund:
TF020873-RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAM
            PREPARATION (BANK EX.),TF024032-TFBH-WATER SANITATION &
            SOLID WASTE WORK PROJECT,TF027097-PHRD-RECONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE PROJECT,TF035313-BOSNIA & HERZEGOVINA -

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia-Herzegovina - Water, Sanitation, and
            Solid Waste Urgent Works Project

abstracts.cdata!:
For the part of the project financed by
            the World Bank and the Italian government, the overall
            outcome of the project is rated as satisfactory. However,
            the project's overall sustainability is rated as
            unlikely. This is due, in part, to country conditions beyond
            the control of the sector as well as because much of the
            reform agenda still remains to be implemented. Overall, Bank
            performance is adjudged satisfactory although it could have
            been more effective regarding institutional strengthening
            and donor coordination. Similarly, Borrower performance is
            rated as satisfactory. Lessons relevant for other emergency
            reconstruction projects are: Although projects of this type
            tend to focus on the more urgent physical investment
            interventions, their eventual sustainability is affected by
            achieving the necessary institutional and policy
            improvements. Project design should therefore include
            explicit objectives to be achieved in a phased manner,
            including improving the financial state of the utilities and
            strengthening management and operations. The Bank should
            take the lead in seeking and achieving donor coordination
            and consistency in key project matters, including the design
            and implementation of the policy and institutional
            framework. The project's content and impact should be
            assessed conservatively, close to the core of Bank financing
            allocated. Implementation arrangements should build on
            locally available expertise, and expatriate technical
            assistance should be limited.

729154.trustfund:
TF035313-BOSNIA & HERZEGOVINA -
            WATER AND SANITATION,TF027097-PHRD-RECONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE PROJECT,TF020873-RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAM
            PREPARATION (BANK EX.),TF024032-TFBH-WATER SANITATION &
            SOLID WASTE WORK PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Water, Sanitation
            and Solid Waste Urgent Works Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Water, Sanitation
            and Solid Waste Urgent Works Project are to: (i) restore
            water, sanitation and solid waste services to the population
            depending on pipe water supply and water borne sewerage
            systems to a level that would mitigate public health risk in
            priority areas; (ii) develop a long term sector strategy and
            the details of an emergency project consistent with the
            strategy; (iii) rebuild and strengthen sector institutions
            so that the improvements will be sustainable; and (iv)
            prepare final designs and bidding documents for the
            rehabilitation project. The project consists of five parts:
            (a) the supply of equipment and materials, including pipe,
            fittings, spare parts and rolling stock for water, sewerage
            and solid waste disposal operating organizations to meet
            urgent requirements for systems operations; (b) urgent works
            for the provision of water supply, sanitation and solid
            waste services for municipalities, including rehabilitation
            and repair of water sources and distribution networks; (c)
            emergency development plan for the water management sector;
            (d) institutional strengthening, focusing on strategic
            planning and sector organization, project, financial and
            maintenance management, computer skills and reduction of
            unaccounted-for water; and (e) preparation of the water,
            sanitation and solid waste rehabilitation project.
